Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: When you be back?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Couple a weeks. Don't do nothin' you wouldn't want me to hear about!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How about a lift, mister?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Can't you see that sticker?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure I see it. But a good guy don't pay no attention to what some heel makes him stick on his truck.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Scrunch down on the running board till we get around the bend.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Goin' far?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Just a few miles. I'd a walked her if my dogs wasn't pooped out.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Lookin' for a job?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, my old man got a place, forty acres. He's a sharecropper, but we been there a long time.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Been doin' a job?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I seen your hands. You been swinging a pick or a sledge--that shines up your hands. I notice little things like that all the time.  Got a trade?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why don't you get to it, buddy?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Get to what?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You know what I mean. You been givin' me a goin' over ever since I got in. Whyn't you go on and ask me where I been?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I don't stick my nose in nobody's business.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Naw--not much!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I stay in my own yard.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Listen. That big nose of yours been goin' over me like a sheep in a vegetable patch. But I ain't keepin' it a secret. I been in the penitentiary. Been there four years. Like to know anything else?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: You ain't got to get sore.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Go ahead. Ask me anything you want.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I didn't mean nothing.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Me neither. I'm just tryin' to get along without shovin' anybody around, that's all.  See that road up ahead?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's where I get off.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You're about to bust to know what I done, ain't you?  Well, I ain't a guy to let you down.  Homicide!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I never asked you!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure, but you'd a throwed a fit if I hadn't tol' you.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Mmmmm he's my saviour. Mmmmm my saviour, Mmmmmmmmmm my saviour now.  Howdy, friend.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Howdy.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Say, ain't you young Tom Joad--ol' Tom's boy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yeah. On my way home now.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Well, I do declare!  I baptized you, son.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why, you're the preacher!

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: *Used* to be. Not no more. I lost the call.  But not no more. I lost the sperit.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Pa always said you was never cut out to be a preacher.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I got nothin' to preach about no more--that's all. I ain't so sure o' things.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Maybe you should a got yourself a wife.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: At my meetin's I used to get the girls glory-shoutin' till they about passed out. Then, I'd go to comfort 'em--and always end up by lovin' 'em. I'd feel bad, an' pray, an' pray, but it didn't do no good. Next time, do it again. I figgered there just wasn't no hope for me.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I never let one go by me when I could catch her.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: But you wasn't a preacher. A girl was just a girl to you. But to me they was holy vessels. I was savin' their souls.  I ast myself--what *is* this call, the Holy Sperit? Maybe *that's* love. Why, I love everybody so much I'm fit to bust sometimes!  So maybe there ain't no sin an' there ain't no virtue. There's just what people do. Some things folks do is nice, and some ain't so nice. But that's as far as any man's got a right to say.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Have a little snort?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Nice drinkin' liquor.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ought to be. That's fact'ry liquor. Cost me a buck.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Been out travelin' around?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Didn't you hear? It was in the papers.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: No, I never. What?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I been in the penitentiary for four years.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Excuse me for asking.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't mind any more. I'd do what I done again. I killed a guy at a dance. We was drunk. He got a knife in me and I laid him out with a shovel. Knocked his head plumb to squash.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: And you ain't ashamed?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: He had a knife in me. That's why they only gave me seven years. Got out in four--parole.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Ain't you seen your folks since then?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, but I aim to before sundown. Gettin' kind of excited about it, too. Which way you going?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I'll go your way.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Maybe Ma'll have pork for supper. I ain't had pork but four times in four years--every Christmas.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I'll be glad to see you pa. Last time I seen him was at a baptizin', an' he had one a the bigges' doses of the Holy Sperit I ever seen. He go to jumpin' over bushes, howlin' like a dog-wolf in moon-time. Fin'ly he picks hisself out a bush big as a piana an' he let out a squawk an' took a run at that bush. Well, sir, he cleared her but he bust his leg snap in two. They was a travellin' dentist there and he set her, an' I give her a prayin' over, but they wasn't no more Holy Sperit in your pa after that.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Lissen. This wind's fixin't to *do* somepin'!

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Shore it is. It always is, this time a year.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Is it fur?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Just around that next bend.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Your granma was a great one, too. The third time she got religion she go it so powerful she knocked down a full-growed deacon with her fist.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's our place.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: And it ain't any too close, either! We better run!

Speaker: tom's voice
Dialogue: Ma?... Pa?... Ain't nobody here?  Somepin's happened.

Speaker: casy's voice
Dialogue: You got a match?

Speaker: tom's voice
Dialogue: There was some pieces of candle always on a shelf.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They're all gone--or dead.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: They never wrote you nothing?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No. They wasn't people to write.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: This was Ma's. Had 'em for years.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: This used to be mine. I give it to Grampa when I went away.  You reckon they could be dead?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I never heard nothin' about it.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Tommy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Muley! Where's my folks, Muley?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: They gone.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I know that! But *where* they gone?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You remember the preacher, don't you?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I ain't no preacher anymore.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: All right, you remember the *man* then.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Now where is my folks?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Gone--  --over to your Uncle John's. The whole crowd of 'em, two weeks ago. But they can't stay there either, because John's got *his* notice to get off.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: But what's happened?  How come they got to get off? We been here fifty years--same place.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Ever'body got to get off. Ever'body leavin', goin' to California. My folks, your folks, ever'body's folks.  Ever'body but me. I ain't gettin' off.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: But who done it?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Listen!  That's some of what done it--the dusters. Started it, anyway. Blowin' like this, year after year--blowin' the land away, blowin' the crops away, blowin' us away now.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Are you crazy?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: You want to hear what happened?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's what I asked you, ain't it?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: The way it happens--the way it happened to me--the man come one day...

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: Fact of the matter, Muley, after what them dusters done to the land, the tenant system don't work no more. It don't even break even, much less show a profit. One man on a tractor can handle twelve or fourteen of these places. You just pay him a wage and take *all* the crop.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: But we couldn't *do* on any less'n what our share is now.  The chillun ain't gettin' enough to eat as it is, and they're so ragged we'd be shamed if ever'body else's chillun wasn't the same way.

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: I can't help that. All I know is I got my orders. They told me to tell you you got to get off, and that's what I'm telling you.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: You mean get off my own land?

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: Now don't go blaming me. It ain't *my* fault.

Speaker: son
Dialogue: Whose fault is it?

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: You know who owns the land--the Shawnee Land and Cattle Company.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Who's the Shawnee Land and Cattle Comp'ny?

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: It ain't nobody. It's a company.

Speaker: son
Dialogue: They got a pres'dent, ain't they? They got somebody that knows what a shotgun's for, ain't they?

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: But it ain't *his* fault, because the *bank* tells him what to do.

Speaker: son
Dialogue: All right. Where's the bank?

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: Tulsa. But what's the use of picking on him? He ain't anything but the manager, and half crazy hisself, trying to keep up with his orders from the east!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Then who *do* we shoot?

Speaker: the man
Dialogue: Brother, I don't know. If I did I'd tell you. But I just don't know *who's* to blame!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Well, I'm right here to tell you, mister, ain't *nobody* going to push me off *my* land! Grampa took up this land seventy years ago. My pa was born here. We was *all* born on it, and some of us got killed on it, and some died on it. And that's what makes it ourn--bein' born on it, and workin' it, and dyin' on it--and not no piece of paper with writin' on it! So just come on and try to push me off!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: They come. They come and pushed me off.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: They come with the cats.

Speaker: tom's voice
Dialogue: The what?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: The cats--the caterpillar tractors.

Speaker: muley's voice
Dialogue: And for ever' one of 'em ten-fifteen families gets throwed outa their homes--one hundred folks with no place to live but on the road. The Rances, the Perrys, the Peterses, the Joadses--one after another they got throwed out. Half the folks you and me know--throwed right out into the road. The one that got me come a month ago.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: I *tol'* you!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Why, you're Joe Davis's boy!

Speaker: davis
Dialogue: I don't like nobody drawin' a bead on me.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Then what are you doin' this kind a thing for--against your own people?

Speaker: davis
Dialogue: For three dollars a day, that's what I'm doin' it for. I got two little kids. I got a wife and my wife's mother. Them people got to eat. Fust and on'y thing I got to think about is my own folks. What happens to other folks is their lookout.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: But this is *my land*, son. Don't you understand?

Speaker: davis
Dialogue: *Used* to be your land. B'longs to the comp'ny now.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: What's he fixin' to do, ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Hush!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Have it your own way, son, but just as sure as you touch my house with that cat I'm gonna blow you plumb to kingdom come.

Speaker: davis
Dialogue: You ain't gonna blow nobody nowhere. First place, you'd get hung and you know it. For another, it wouldn't be two days before they'd have another guy here to take my place.

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Don't! Please don't!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: I'm tellin' you!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: What was the use. He was right. There wasn't a thing in the world I could do about it.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: But it don't seem possible--kicked off like that!

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: The rest of my fambly set out for the west--there wasn't nothin' to eat--but I couldn't leave. Somepin' wouldn't let me. So now I just wander around. Sleep wherever I am. I used to tell myself I was lookin' out for things, so when they come back ever'thing would be all right. But I knowed that wan't true. There ain't nothin' to look out for. And ain't nobody comin' back. They're gone-- and me, I'm just an 'ol graveyard ghost--that's all in the world I am.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: You think I'm touched.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: No. You're lonely--but you ain't touched.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: It don't matter. If I'm touched, I'm touched, and that's all there is to it.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What I can't understand is my folks takin' it! Like ma! I seen her nearly beat a peddler to death with a live chicken. She aimed to go for him with an ax she had in the other hand but she got mixed up and forgot which hand was which and when she got through with that peddler all she had left was two chicken legs.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: Just a plain 'ol graveyard ghost, that's all.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She's settlin'.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: What you figger to do?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: It's hard to say. Stay here till mornin' an' then go on over to Uncle John's, I reckon. After that I don't know.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: That's them! Them lights! Come on, we got to hide out!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hide out for what? We ain't doin' nothin'.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: You're *trespassin'*! It ain't you lan' no more! An' that's the supr'tendant--with a gun!

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Come on, Tom. You're on parole.

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: All you got to do is lay down an' watch.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Won't they come out here?

Speaker: muley
Dialogue: I don't think so. One come out here once an' I clipped him from behin' with a fence stake. They ain't bothered since.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: He ain't here.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Anybody ever 'tol me I'd be hidin' out on my own place...!

Speaker: ma's voice
Dialogue: Lord, make us thankful for what we are about to receive, for His sake. Amen.

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I seen you!--You et durin' grace!

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: One little ole dab!--one teeny little ole dab!

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Ain't he messy though!

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I seen him!--gobblin' away like an ole pig!

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Whyn't you keep your eyes shet durin' grace, you ole...

Speaker: noah
Dialogue: What's it say again?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Says plenty work in California-- peaches. Eight hundred pickers needed.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Wait'll I get to California! Gonna reach up and pick me an orange whenever I want it! Or grapes. That there's somethin' I ain't *never* had enough of! Gonna get me a whole bunch a grapes off a bush and I'm gonna squash 'em all over my face and just let the juice dreen down offen my chin!

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: Puh-raise the Lawd for vittory!

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: I shore would like to do that!

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Look. I'm Grampa!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Tommy, you didn't *bust* out, didya? You ain't got to hide, have you?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, Ma. I'm paroled. I got my papers.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I was so scared we was goin' away without you--and we'd never see each other again.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'd a found you, Ma.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Muley tol' me what happened, Ma. Are we goin' to California true?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: We *got* to, Tommy. But that's gonna be awright. I seen the han'bills, about how much work they is, an' high wages, too. But I gotta fin' out somepin' else first, Tommy.  Did they hurt you, son? Did they hurt you an' make you mean-mad?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mad, Ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Sometimes they do.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, Ma I was at first--but not no more.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Sometimes they do somethin' to you, Tommy. They hurt you--and you get mad--and then you get mean--and they hurt you again--and you get meaner, and meaner--till you ain't no boy or no man any more, but just a walkin' chunk a mean-mad. Did they hurt you like that, Tommy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, Ma. You don't have to worry about that.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Thank God. I--I don't want no mean son

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: What'd you do, son--bust out?

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: I knowed it! Couldn't keep him in! Can't keep a Joad in! I knowed it from the fust!

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: You know what I al'ays said: "Tom'll come bustin' outa that jail like a bull through a corral fence." Can't keep no Joad in jail!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I didn't bust out. They lemme out. Howya, Noah. Howya, Uncle John.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: I was the same way myself. Put me in jail and I'd bust right out. Couldn't hold me!

Speaker: noah
Dialogue: Bust out?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Parole.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Rosasharn! Hi, Rosasharn! Howya, Al!

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: The jailbird's back! The jailbird's back!

Speaker: omnes
Dialogue: Hi, Ma! Hi, Connie! Hiya, Grampa!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: She's due about three-four months.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why, she wasn't no more'n a kid when I went up.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: You bust outa jail, Tom?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Naw. They paroled me.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Heh'o Tom.  This is Connie, my husband.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, I see you been busy already!

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: You do not see either!--not yet!

Speaker: omnes
Dialogue: Lookut his face! Y'see his face? Lookut Rosasharn! Y'ever see anything like her face when Tom said it? Look around, Rosasharn! Let's see it again!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Hey, Joad! John Joad!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Ain't forgot, have you?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: We ain't forgot.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Comin' through here tomorrow, you know.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I know. We be out. We be out by sunup.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How you get all this money?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Sol' things, chopped cotton--even Grampa. Got us about two hunnerd dollars all tol'. Shucked out seventy- five for this truck, but we still got nearly a hunnerd and fifty to set out on. I figger we oughta be able to make it on that.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Easy. After all, they ain't but about *twelve* of us, is they?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: She'll prob'ly ride like a bull calf-- but she'll ride!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Reckon we better begin roustin' 'em out if we aim to get outa here by daylight. How about it, John? How you boys comin'?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How about it, Ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I'm ready.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Rosasharn honey! Wake up the chillun. We're fixin' to leave.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Where's Grampa? Al, go git him.

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I'm gonna sit up front! Somebody he'p me!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: You kids climb up first, on top.  Al's gonna drive, Ma. You sit up there with him and Granma and we'll swap around later.

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I ain't gonna sit with Grampa!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Connie, you he'p Rosasharn up there alongside Ruthie and Winfiel'.  Where's Grampa?

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: Where he al'ays is, prob'ly!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Well, leave him a place, but Noah, you and John, y'all kinda find yourself a place--kinda keep it even all around.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Think she'll hold?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: If she does it'll be a miracle outa Scripture.

Speaker: grampa's voice
Dialogue: Lemmo go, gol dang it! Lemmo go, I tell you!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: He wasn't sleepin'. He was settin' out back a the barn. They's somepin' wrong with him.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Ef you don't let me go--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What's the matter, Grampa?

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Ain't nothin' the matter. I just ain't a-goin', that's all.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: What you mean you ain't goin'? We *got* to go. We got no place to stay.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: I ain't talkin' about you, I'm talkin' about me. And I'm a-stayin'. I give her a good goin' over all night long-- and I'm a-stayin'.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: But you can't *do* that, Grampa. This here land is goin' under the tractor. We *all* got to git out.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: All but me! I'm a-stayin'.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How 'bout Granma?

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Take her with you!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: But who'd cook for you? How'd you live?

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Muley's livin', ain't he? And I'm *twicet* the man Muley is!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Now listen, Grampa. Listen to me, just a minute.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: --but it's mine.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Grampa, his eyes hurt and hunted and frightened and bewildered, scratches in the dirt.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: And can't nobody *make* me go, either! Ain't nobody here *man* enough to make me! I'm a-stayin'.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Either we got to tie him up and *throw* him on the truck, or somepin. He can't stay here.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Can't tie him. Either we'll hurt him or he'll git so mad he'll hurt his self.  Reckon we could git him *drunk*?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ain't no whisky, is they?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Wait. There's a half a bottle a soothin' sirup here.  It put the chillun to sleep.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Don't taste bad.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: And they's some coffee here. I could fix him a cup...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's right. And douse some in it.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Better give him a good 'un. He's awful bull-headed.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: I smell spareribs. Somebody been eatin' spareribs? How come I ain't got some?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Got some saved for you, Grampa. Got 'em warmin' now. Here's a cuppa coffee.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Awright, but get me some a them spareribs, too. Get me a whole mess of 'em. I'm hongry.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: I shore do like spareribs.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Easy, *easy!* You wanta bust his head wide open? Pull his arms, John.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: Ain't a-goin', thas all...

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Put somepin' over him, so he won't git sun-struck.  Awright, Al, letta go!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: You be awright, Grampa.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Good-by, an' good luck.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Hey, wait! Hold 'er, Al!  Ain't you goin' with us?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I'd like to. There's somethin' happenin' out there in the wes' an' I'd like to try to learn what it is. If you feel you got the room...

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Come on, get on, plenty room!

Speaker: omnes
Dialogue: Sure, come on, Casy, plenty room!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Here we go!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: California, here we come!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Ain't you gonna look back, Ma?--give the ol' place a last look?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: We're goin' to California, ain't we? Awright then, let's *go* to California.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: That don't sound like you, Ma. You never was like that before.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I never had my house pushed over before. I never had my fambly stuck out on the road. I never had to lose... ever'thing I had in life.

Speaker: grampa
Dialogue: *Ain't* a-goin'... ain't a-goin'...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: 'S all right, Grampa. You just kind a tar'd, that's all. Somebody fix a pallet.

Speaker: tom's voice
Dialogue: This here is William James Joad, dyed of a stroke, old old man. His folkes bured him becaws they got no money to pay for funerls. Nobody kilt him. Jus a stroke an he dyed.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I figger best we leave something like this on him, lest somebody dig him up and make out he been kilt.  Lotta times looks like the gov'ment got more interest in a dead man than a live one.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Not be so lonesome, either, knowin' his name is there with 'im, not just' a old fella lonesome underground.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Casy, won't you say a few words?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I ain't no more a preacher, you know.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We know. But ain't none of our folks ever been buried without a few words.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: This here ol' man jus' lived a life an' jus' died out of it. I don't know whether he was good or bad, an' it don't matter much. Heard a fella say a poem once, an' he says, "All that lives is holy." But I wouldn't pray for jus' a ol' man that's dead, because he's awright. If I was to pray I'd pray for the folks that's alive an' don't know which way to turn. Grampa here, he ain't got no more trouble like that. He's got his job all cut out for 'im--so cover 'im up and let 'im get to it.

Speaker: omnes
Dialogue: Amen.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Tommy.

Speaker: tommy
Dialogue: What is it, Ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Wasn't that the state line we just passed?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yes'm, that was it.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Your pa tol' me you didn't ought to cross it if you're paroled. Says they'll send you up again.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Forget it, Ma. I got her figgered out. Long as I keep outa trouble, ain't nobody gonna say a thing. All I gotta do is keep my nose clean.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Maybe they got crimes in California we don't know about. Crimes we don't even know *is* crimes.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Forget it, Ma. Jus' think about the nice things out there. Think about them grapes and oranges--an' ever'body got work--

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I gotta git out!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: First gas station, Granma--

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I gotta git *out*, I tell ya! I gotta git *out*!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Awright! Awright!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They shore don't waste no time!  Take her out.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Get goin', buddy. No campin' here.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We ain't campin'. We jus' stoppin' a minute--

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Lissen, I heard that before--

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I tell ya I gotta git out!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She's kinda ol'--

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: I tell ya--

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Okay, okay!

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: Puh-raise the Lawd for vittory!

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Ma... all this, will it hurt the baby?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Now don't you go gettin' nimsy-mimsy.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Sometimes I'm all jumpy inside.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Well, can't nobody get through nine *months* without sorrow.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: But will it--hurt the baby?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: They use' to be a sayin': A chile born outa sorrow'll be a happy chile. An' another: Born outa too much joy'll be a doleful boy. That's the way I always heard it.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: You don't ever get scairt, do you, Ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: --I'll do it.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Don't it ever scare you it won't be nice in California like we think?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: That's my part--that an' keepin' the fambly together.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Thas my son-in-law.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: Sings real nice. What state y'all from?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Oklahoma. Had us a farm there, share- croppin'.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Till the tractors druv us out.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: We from Arkansas. I had me a store there, kind of general notions store, but when the farms went the store went too.  Nice a little as you ever saw. I shore did hate to give it up.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Wal, y'cain't tell. I figure when we git out there an' git work an' maybe git us a piece a growin' lan' near water it might not be so bad at that.

Speaker: other men
Dialogue: Thas right... Payin' good wages, I hear... Ever'body got work out there... Can't be no worse...

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: You folks must have a pot a money.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: No, we ain't got no money. But they's plenty of us to work, an' we 're all good men. Get good wages out there an' put it all together an' we'll be awright.

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Good wages, eh! Pickin' oranges an' peaches?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: We gonna take whatever they got.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What's so funny about it?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: What's so funny about it?  I just *been* out there! I been an' *seen* it! An' I'm goin' *back* to starve-- because I ruther starve all over at once!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Whatta you think you're talkin' about? I got a han'bill here says good wages, an' I seen it in the papers they need pickers!

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Awright, go on! Ain't nobody stoppin' ya!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: But what about this?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: I ain't gonna fret you. Go on!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Wait a minute, buddy. You jus' done some jackassin'! You ain't gonna shut up now. The han'bill says they need men. You laugh an' say they don't. Now which one's a liar?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: How many you'all got them han'bills? Come on, how many?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: But what does *that* prove?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Look at 'em! Same yella han'bill-- 800 pickers wanted. Awright, this man wants 800 men. So he prints up 5,000 a them han'bills an' maybe 20,000 people sees 'em. An' maybe two-three thousan' starts movin, wes' account a this han'bill. Two- three thousan' folks that's crazy with worry headin' out for 800 jobs! Does that make sense?

Speaker: proprietor
Dialogue: What are you, a troublemaker? You sure you ain't one a them labor fakes?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: I swear I ain't, mister!

Speaker: proprietor
Dialogue: Well, don't you go roun' here tryin' to stir up trouble.

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Heart-failure!--an' their little bellies stuck out like a pig-bladder!

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: Well--gettin' late. Got to get to sleep.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: S'pose he's tellin' the truth--that fella?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: He's tellin' the truth awright. The truth for him. He wasn't makin' nothin' up.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How about us? Is that the truth for us?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: How can you tell?

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: You folks aim to buy anything?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Need some gas, mister.

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: Got any money?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Whatta you think:--we's beggin'?

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: I just ast, that's all.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, ask right. You ain't talkin' to bums, you know.

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: All in the worl' I done was ast!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Kinda pie y'got?

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Banana cream, pineapple cream, chocolate cream--and apple.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Cut me off a hunk a that banana cream, and a cuppa java.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Make it two.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Two it is.  Seen any new etchin's lately, Bill?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well, here's one ain't bad. Little kid comes in late to school. Teacher says--

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Could you see your way clear to sell us a loaf of bread, ma'am.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: This ain't a groc'ry store. We got bread to make san'widges with.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: I know, ma'am... on'y it's for a ole lady, no teeth, gotta sof'n it with water so she can chew it, an' she's hongry.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Whyn't you buy a san'wich? We got nice san'widges.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: I shore would like to do that, ma'am, but the fack is, we ain't got but a dime for it. It's all figgered out, I mean--for the trip.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: You can't get no loaf a bread for a dime. We only got fifteen-cent loafs.

Speaker: bert
Dialogue: Give 'em the bread.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: We'll run out 'fore the bread truck comes.

Speaker: bert
Dialogue: Awright then, run out!

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: This here's a fifteen-cent loaf.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Would you--could you see your way to cuttin' off ten cents worth?

Speaker: bert
Dialogue: Give 'im the loaf!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: No, sir, we wanta buy ten cents worth, thas all.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: You can have this for ten cents.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: I don't wanta rob you, ma'am.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Go ahead--Bert says take it.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: May soun' funny to be so tight, but we got a thousan' miles to go, an' we don't know if we'll make it.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Is them penny candy, ma'am?

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Which ones?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: There, them stripy ones.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Oh, them? Well, no--them's *two* for a penny.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Well, give me two then, ma'am.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Sure, take 'em, take 'em!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Thank you, ma'am.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Them wasn't two-for-a-cent candy.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: What's it to you?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Them was nickel apiece candy.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: We got to get goin'. We're droppin' time.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: So long.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Hey, wait a minute. You got change comin'.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: What's it to you?

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Bert.

Speaker: bert
Dialogue: What ya want?

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Look here.

Speaker: mae
Dialogue: Truck drivers.

Speaker: bert
Dialogue: I figgered No. 3 was about ready to pay off.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Where you going?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: California.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: How long you plan to be in Arizona?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No longer'n we can get acrost her.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Got any plants?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No plants.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Okay. Go ahead, but you better keep movin'.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure. We aim to.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: There she is, folks--the land a milk an' honey--California!

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: Well, if *that's* what we come out here for...

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Maybe it's nice on the other side. Them pitchers--them little pos'cards-- they was real pretty.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Aw, sure. This here's jus' a part of it. Ain't no sense a gettin' scairt right off.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Course not. Come on, let's get goin'. She don't look so tough to me!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Got that desert yet. Gotta take her tonight. Take her in the daytime fella says she'll cut your gizzard out.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: How's Granma since we got her in the tent?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: She's off her chump, seems to me.

Speaker: noah
Dialogue: She's outa her senses, awright. All night on the truck keep talkin' like she was talkin' to Grampa.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She's jus' wore out, that's all.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: I shore would like to stop here a while an' give her some res' but we on'y got 'bout forty dollars left. I won't feel right till we're there an' all workin' an' a little money comin' in.

Speaker: noah
Dialogue: Like to jus' stay here myself. Like to lay here forever. Never get hungry an' never get sad. Lay in the water all life long, lazy as a brood sow in the mud.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Wonder if we'll ever get in a place where folks can live 'thout fightin' hard scrabble an' rock. Sometimes you get to thinkin' they *ain't* no such country.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: How's the swimmin'?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Dunno. We ain't tried none. Sure feels good to set here, though.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Mind if we come in an' set?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She ain't our river. But we'll len' you a little piece of her.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Goin' west?

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Nope. We come from there. Goin' back home.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Where's home?

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Panhandle, come from near Pampa.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Can you make a livin' there?

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: But at leas' we can starve to death with folks we know.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Ya know, you're the second fella talked like that. I'd like to hear some more about that.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Me an' you both.

Speaker: son
Dialogue: He ain't gonna tell you nothin' about it.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: If a fella's willin' to work hard, can't he cut her?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Listen, mister. I don't know ever'thing. You might go out an' fall into a steady job, an' I'd be a liar. An' then, you might never get no work, an' I didn't warn you. All I can tell ya, most of the folks is purty mis'able.  But a fella don't know ever'thing.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: John, you never was a fella to say much, but I'll be goldanged if you opened your mouth twicet since we lef' home. What you think about this?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I don't think *nothin'* about it. We're a-goin' there, ain't we?  When we get there, we'll get there. When we get a job, we'll work, an' when we don't get a job we'll set on our behin's. That's all they is to it, ain't it?

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: You people got a lotta nerve.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What you mean?

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: Crossin' the desert in a jalopy like this.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You been acrost?

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: Sure, plenty, but not in no wreck like this.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: If we broke down maybe somebody'd give us a han'.

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: Well, maybe. But I'd hate to be doin' it. Takes more nerve than I got.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Don't you worry, Granma. It's gonna be awright.

Speaker: granma
Dialogue: Grampa... Grampa... I want Grampa...

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Don't you fret now.

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: Holy Moses, what a hard-lookin' outfit!

Speaker: second boy
Dialogue: All them Okies is hard-lookin'.

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: Boy, but I'd hate to hit that desert in a jalopy like that!

Speaker: second boy
Dialogue: Well, you and me got sense. Them Okies got no sense or no feeling. They ain't human. A human being wouldn't live like they do. A human being couldn't stand it to be so miserable.

Speaker: first boy
Dialogue: Just don't know any better, I guess.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: What a place! How'd you like to walk acrost her?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: People done it. If they could, we could.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Lots must a died, too.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, we ain't out a it yet.

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: This here's the desert an' we're right in it!

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: I wisht it was day.

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Tom says if it's day it'll cut you gizzard smack out a you.  I seen a pitcher once. They was bones ever'place.

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: Man bones?

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Some, I guess, but mos'ly cow bones.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: 'S awright, honey. Everything's gonna be awright.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Seems like we wasn't never gonna do nothin' but move. I'm so tar'd.

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: Women is always tar'd.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: You ain't--you ain't sorry, are you, honey?

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: No, but--but you seen that advertisement in the Spicy Western Story magazine. Don't pay nothin'. Jus' send 'em the coupon an' you're a radio expert--nice clean work.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: But we can still do it, honey.

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: I ought to done it then--an' not come on any trip like this.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: We can't give up, honey. The family's got to get acrost. You know that.

Speaker: john's voice
Dialogue: Ever'thing all right?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Yes, ever'thing's all right. I--I guess I dropped off to sleep.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What's this here?

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Agricultural inspection. We got to go over your stuff. Got any vegetables or seed?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Well, we got to look over your stuff. You got to unload.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Look, mister. We got a sick ol' lady. We got to get her to a doctor. We can't wait.  You can't make us wait!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Yeah? Well, we got to look you over.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I swear we ain't got anything. I swear it. An' Granma's awful sick.  Look!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: You wasn't foolin'! You swear you got no fruit or vegetables?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: No, I swear it.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Then go ahead. You can get a doctor at Barstow. That's just eight miles. But don't stop. Don't get off. Understand?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Okay, cap. Much oblige.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Tell Tom he don't have to stop. Granma's all right.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Will ya look at her!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: I never knowed they was anything like her!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Where's Ma? I want Ma to see it. Look, Ma! Come here, Ma!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ma, you sick?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Ya say we're acrost?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Look, Ma!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Thank God!  An' we're still together-- most of us.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Didn' you get no sleep?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Was Granma bad?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Granma's dead.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Since before they stopped us las' night.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: An' that's why you didn't want 'em to look?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I was afraid they'd stop us an' wouldn't let us cross. But I tol' Granma. I tol' her when she was dyin'. I tol' her the fambly had ta get acrost. I tol' her we couldn't take no chances on bein' stopped.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: She got to lay her head down in California after all.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: How far you figger you gonna get *this* way?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Right here. We give out a gas.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Where's the bes' place to get some work aroun' here?  Don't matter what kin' either.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: If I seen one a them things I must a seen ten thousan'.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Ain't it no good?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Not here--not now. Month ago there was some pickin' but it's all moved south now. Where'bouts in Oklahoma you from?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sallisaw.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: I come out from Cherokee County--two years ago.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Why, Connie's folks from Cherokee County--

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Okay, ma'am, let's don't go into it. I already met about a hundred firs' cousins an' it mus' be five hundred secon'. But this is what I got to tell you, don't try to park in town tonight. Keep on out to that camp. If we catch you in town after dark we got to lock you up. Don't forget.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: But what we gonna *do*?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: But I don't min' tellin' you, the guy they *ought* to lock up is the guy that sent out *them* things.

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: How many, folks?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: One.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She shore don't look prosperous. Want to go somewheres else?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: On a gallon a gas?  Let's set up the tent. Maybe I can fix us up some stew.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I could break up some bresh if you want me, ma'am.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You want to get ast to eat, hunh?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Didn' you have no breakfast?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: No, ma'am. They ain't no work hereabouts. Pa's in tryin' to sell some stuff to get gas so's we can get along.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Didn' none of these have no breakfast?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I did. Me an' my brother did. We et good.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Then you ain't hungry, are you?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Well, it's a good thing *some* a you ain't hungry, because they ain't enough to go all the way roun'.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Aw, he was braggin'. Know what he done? Las' night, come out an' say they got chicken to eat. Well, sir, I looked in whilst they was a-eatin' an' it was fried dough jus' like ever'body else.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: How 'bout it?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I dunno what to do. I got to feed the fambly. What'm I gonna do with these here?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I ain't hungry.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Whatta ya mean? You ain't et today.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I know, but I got a stomickache. I ain't hungry.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You take that plate inside the tent an' you eat it.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Wouldn't be no use. I'd still see 'em inside the tent.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You git. Go on now, git. You ain't doin' no good. They ain't enough for you.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: We can't send 'em away. Take your plates an' go inside. Take a plate to Rosasharn.  They ain't enough. All you gonna get is jus' a taste but--I can't help it, I can't keep it from you.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I done fine! Now nobody got enough!

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: You men want to work?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Sure we wanta work. Where's it at?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Tulare County. Fruit's opening up. Need a lot of pickers.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: You doin' the hirin'?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Well, I'm contracting the land.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: Whay you payin?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Well, can't tell exactly, yet. 'Bout thirty cents, I guess.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: Why can't you tell? You took the contrac', didn' you?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: That's true. But it's keyed to the price. Might be a little more, might be a little less.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: All right, mister. I'll go. You just show your license to contrack, an' then you make out a order--where an' when an' how much you gonna pay--an' you sign it an' we'll go.

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: You trying to tell me how to run my own business?

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: 'F we're workin' for you, it's our business too. An' how do we know--  --you ain't one a the guys that sent these things out?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Listen, Smart Guy. I'll run my business my own way. I got work. If you wanta take it, okay. If not, just sit here, that's all.

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: Twicet now I've fell for that line. Maybe he needs a thousan' men. So he get's five thousan' there, an' he'll pay fifteen cents a hour. An' you guys'll have to take it 'cause you'll be hungry.  'F he wants to hire men, let him write it out an' say what he's gonna pay. Ast to see his license. He ain't allowed by law to contrack men without a license.

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Joe!

Speaker: floyd
Dialogue: You see? If this guy was on the level, would he bring a cop along?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: What's the trouble?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: Ever see this guy before?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: What'd he do?

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: He's agitatin'.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Hmmm.  Get in that car.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You got nothin' on him.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Open your trap again and you'll go too.

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: You fellas don't wanta lissen to troublemakers. You better pack up an' come on to Tulare County.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Might be a good idea to do what he says. Too many of you Okies aroun' here already. Folks beginnin' to figger it ain't maybe *safe*. Might start a epidemic or sump'n.  Wouldn't like a bunch a guys down here with pick handles tonight, would you?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Now, you.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Gimme that gun. Now git outa here. Go down in them willows an' wait.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I ain't gonna run.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: He seen you, Tom! You wanta be fingerprinted? You wanta get sent back for breakin' parole?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You're right!

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Hide in the willows. If it's awright to come back I'll give you four high whistles.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Go on. Get in your tent. You don't know nothin'.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: How 'bout you?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: An' I ain't doin' nothin' but set around.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: But ain't no reason--

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Lissen. I don't care nothin' about you, but if you mess in this, your whole fambly li'ble to get in trouble, an' Tom get sent back to the penitentiary.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Okay. I think you're a darn fool, though.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Sure. Why not?

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: What's goin' on here?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: This man a yours, he got tough an' I hit him. Then he started shootin'-- hit a woman down the line--so I hit him again.

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Well--what'd you do in the first place?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I talked back.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: They's a woman down there like to bleed to death from his bad shootin'.

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Mike, is this the fella that hit you?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Don't look like him.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: It was me, all right. You just got smart with the wrong fella.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Don't look like him, but... maybe it was. I ain't sure.

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Get in that car.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Boy, what a mess a .45 does make! They got a tourniquet on. We'll send a doctor out.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: But what you gonna do? Must be *thousands* of 'em around here, sore and hungry and living in them dumps. What you gonna do about 'em?

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: You gotta hold 'em down. Hold 'em down or they'll take over the whole country. That's all you *can* do.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Well, they ain't gonna take over *my* country. I been livin' here too long for *that*. Maybe some a the boys better drop around tonight and give 'em something to think about.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Leave him alone, Ma--Al's just billy- goatin' around--

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Sure! I was just aimin' to meet up with a couple girls I know.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You don't know *no* girls around here. You're lyin', *You're runnin' away*!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Cut it out, Ma, or I'll--

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You'll *what*?... Come on, Pa. Come on an' whup me. Jus' try it.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Now don't get sassy, Ma.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Al ain't a-goin' away, an' you gonna *tell* him he ain't a-goin' away.  An' if you think diff'unt, you gotta whup me first. So some on.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: An' she ain't so young, neither!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: I'd come back--

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: But ef you *do* whup me, I swear you better not ever go to sleep again, because the minute you go to sleep, or you're settin' down, or your back's turned, I'm gonna knock you belly-up with a bucket.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Jus' sassy, that's all.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Sassy my foot! I'm jus' sick and tar'd a my folks tryin' to bust up. All we got lef' in the *worl'* is the fambly--an' right down at bottom that's all we *got* to have! Ef some of us dies, we can't he'p that--but ain't nobody else runnin' away!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: But it ain't runnin' away, Ma. All I wanta do is go away with another fella an' look aroun' for work by ourself--

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: --an' I'm here to tell ya ef anybody else tries to bust us up anymore I'm a-goin' cat wild with this here piece a bar-arn!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hey, Al!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Tom? You can come on. They gone.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We got to get outa here right away. Ever'body here? Where's Uncle John?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Here I am.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: What's a matter now?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Fella tells me some a them poolroom boys figgerin' to burn the whole camp out tonight. Got to get that truck loaded--what you doin' with the jack-handle, Ma?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Awright, you can fight it out later. Right now we got to hustle. Where's Connie?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Lit out this e'enin'--said he didn't know it was gonna be like this.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Glad to get shet of him. Never was no good an' never will be--

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Pa! Shh!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: How come I got to shh? Run out, didn't he?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Don't fret, honey. You goin' to be awright.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Tom, I jus' don't feel like nothin' a tall. Without him I jus' don't wanta live.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Maybe he'll be back. We'll leave word for him. Jus' don't cry.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Just in case. Sit up back an' if anybody tries to climb up--let 'im have it.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: I ain't got nothin' in *my* han'.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Maybe Connie went to get some books to study up with. He's gonna be a radio expert, ya know. Maybe he figgered to suprise us.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Maybe that's jus' what he done.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ma, they comes a time when a man gets mad.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Tom--you tol' me--you promised you wasn't like that. You promised me.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I know, Ma. I'm a tryin'. If it was the law they was workin' with, we could take it. But it *ain't* the law. They're workin' away at our spirits. They're tryin' to make us cringe an' crawl. They're workin' on our decency.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You promised, Tommy.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm a-tryin', Ma. Honest I am.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You gotta keep clear, Tom. The fambly's breakin' up. You *got* to keep clear.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What's that--detour?

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Where you think you're goin'?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well--  --we're strangers here. We heard about they's work in a place called Tulare.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Well, you're goin' the wrong way, an' what's more, we don't want no more Okies in this town. We ain't got work enough for them that are already here.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Which way is it at, mister?

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: You turn right aroun' and head north. An' don't come back till the cotton's ready.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Don't you min', Tommy. You done good. You done jus' good.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: An' Rosasharn, we got to remember she's gonna be due soon.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: It sure is hell jus' tryin' to get enough to eat.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Fella tells me they's three hunerd thousan' aroun' here like us, a- scrabblin' for work an' livin' like hogs. Can't figger what it is, but *sump'n's* wrong.

Speaker: spencer
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: spencer
Dialogue: You people looking for work?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mister, we're lookin' even under boards for work.

Speaker: spencer
Dialogue: Can you pick peaches?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We can pick anything.

Speaker: spencer
Dialogue: Well, there's plenty of work for you about forty miles north, this road just outside Pixley. Turn east on 32 and look for Hooper's ranch. Tell 'em Spencer sent you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mister, we sure that ya!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Fust thing I'll get is coffee, cause ever'body been wantin' that, an' then some flour an' bakin' powder an' meat. Better not get no side- meat right off. Save that for later. Maybe Sat'dy. Got to get some soap too. An' milk. Rosasharn's got to have some milk.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get some sugar too, for the coffee.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You know, I jus' can't remember when I felt so good before!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Know what I'm a-gonna do? I'm a-gonna save up an' go in town an' get me a job in a garage. Live in a room an' eat in restaurants. Go to the movin' pitchers *ever'* night. Cowboy pitchers.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: What is it, a wreck?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Where you think you're going?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Fella named Spencer sent us--said they was work pickin' peaches.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Want to work, do you?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure do.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Pull up behind that car.  Okay for this one. Take 'em through.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What's the matter? What's happened?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Little trouble up ahead, but you'll get through. Just follow the line.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Maybe the road's out.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't know what these cops got to do with it but I don't like it.  An' these here are our own people, all of 'em. I don't like this.

Speaker: men
Dialogue: Go on, go on! Keep movin'!

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Want to work?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure, but what is this?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: That's not your affair. Name.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Joad.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: How many men?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Four.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Women?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Kids?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Can all of you work?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why, I guess so.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Okay. House 63. Wages 5 cents a box. No bruised fruit. Move along and go to work right away.

Speaker: first deputy
Dialogue: Name.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Joad. Say, what is this here?

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Not here. Take a look at his license.

Speaker: first deputy
Dialogue: 542-567 Oklahoma.

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Ain't got it. Guess they're okay.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They sure do want to make us feel at home all right.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: We gonna live here?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Why, sure. It won't be so bad once we get her washed out.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: I like the tent better.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: This got a floor. Wouldn't leak when it rains.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Name?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: It's still Joad.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: All y'all go. Me an' Rosasharn'll unload.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Got any more, Ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: No. That's all. You made a dollar, an' that's a dollar's worth.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: That!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: They charge extry at the comp'ny store but they ain't no other place.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I ain't full.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Well, tomorra you'll get in a full day--full day's pay--an' we'll have plenty.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: You wouldn't think jus' reachin' up an' pickin'd get you in the back.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Think I'll walk out an' try to fin' out what all that fuss outside the gate was. Anybody wanta come with me?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: No. I'm jus' gonna set awhile an' then go to bed.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Think I'll look aroun' an' see if I can't meet me a girl.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Thing's been workin' on me, what they was yellin' about. Got me all curious.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I got to get a lot curiouser than I am--with all them cops out there.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Okay. I be back a little later.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You be careful, Tommy. Don't you be stickin' your nose in anything.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Okay, Ma. Don't you worry.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Where you think you're going?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Thought I'd take a walk. Any law against it?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Well, you just turn around and walk the other way.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You mean I can't even get outa here?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back?--or you want me to whistle up some help and take you back?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'll walk back.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Evenin'.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Jus' goin' pas', that's all.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: Know anybody here?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No. Jus' goin' pas', I tell you.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Casy! What you doin' here?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Well, if it ain't Tom Joad. How ya, boy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Thought you was in jail.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: No, I done my time an' got out. Come on in.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: This the fella you been talkin' about?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: This is him. What you doin' here, Tommy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Workin'. Pickin' peaches. But I seen a bunch a fellas yellin' when we come in, so I come out to see what's goin' on. What's it all about?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: This here's a strike.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, fi' cents a box ain't much, but a fella can eat.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Fi' cents! They pain' you fi' cents?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure. We made a buck since midday.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: So we says we won't take it. So they druv us off. Now they're payin' you five--but when they bust this strike ya think they'll pay five?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I dunno. Payin' five now.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I don't expeck we can las' much longer-- some a the folks ain't et for two days. You goin' back tonight?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I aim to.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Well--tell the folks inside how it is, Tom. Tell 'em they're starvin' us and stabbin' theirself in the back. An' as sure as God made little apples it's goin' back to two an' a half jus' as soon as they clear us out.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You hear sump'n?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'll tell 'em. But I don't know how. Never seen so many guys with guns. Wouldn't even let us talk today.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Try an' tell 'em, Tom. They'll get two an' a half, jus' the minute we're gone. An' you know what that is? That's one ton a peaches picked an' carried for a dollar. That way you can't even buy food enough to keep you alive! Tell 'em to come out with us, Tom! Them peaches is *ripe*. Two days out an' they'll pay *all* of us five!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They won't. They're a-gettin' five an' they don't care about nothin' else.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: But jus' the minute they ain't strike- breakin' they won't get no five!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: An' the nex' thing you know you'll be out, because they got it all figgered down to a T--until the harvest is in you're a *migrant* worker--afterwards, just a bum.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Five they're a-gettin' now, an' that's all they're int'rested in. I know exackly what Pa'd say. He'd jus' say it wasn't none a his business.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I guess that's right. Have to take a beatin' before he'll know.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We was outa food. Tonight we had meat. Not much, but we had it. Think Pa's gonna give up his meat on account a other fellas? An' Rosasharn needs milk. Think Ma's gonna starve that baby jus' cause a bunch a fellas is yellin' outside a gate?

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: I don't. I got to *ask*.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: I don't like it.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: Can't tell. Seems like I hear sump'n, an' then I listen an' they ain't nothin' to hear.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: All of us a little itchy. Cops been tellin' us how they gonna beat us up an' run us outa the country. Not them reg'lar deppities, but them tin- star fellas they got for guards.  They figger I'm the leader because I talk so much.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Turn out that light an' come outside. They's sump'n here.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I dunno. Listen.

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Can't tell if you hear it or not. You hear it, Tom?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I hear it. I think they's some guys comin' this way, lots of 'em. We better get outa here.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: Down that way--under the bridge span.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: There they are! Stand where you are!

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: That's him! That one in the middle, the skinny one! Chuck! Alec! Here they are! We got 'em!

Speaker: casy
Dialogue: Listen, you fellas. You don't know what you're doin'. You're helpin' to stave kids.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Shut up, you red--

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Looks like to me you killed him.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Turn him over. Put the light on him.

Speaker: deputy's voice
Dialogue: Serves him right, too.

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: Where's that flash?

Speaker: third deputy
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: third deputy
Dialogue: Boy, he's *good* and dead! You see that fella that done it?

Speaker: second deputy
Dialogue: I ain't sure--but I caught him one across the face, and believe me, I give him a trade-mark *he* ain't gonna be able to shake off easy!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Anybody ask anything?

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: No'm.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Stand by the door.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: How's it feel, Tommy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Busted my cheek but I can still see. What'd you hear?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Looks like you done it.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I kinda thought so. Felt like it.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Folks ain't talkin' about much else. They say they got posses out. Talkin' about a lynchin'--when they catch the fella.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They killed Casy first.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: That ain't the way they're tellin' it. They're sayin' you done it fust.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They know what--this fella looks like?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: They know he got hit in the face.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Ma. But--I didn't know what I was doin', no more'n when you take a breath. I didn't even know I was gonna do it.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: It's awright, Tommy. I wisht you didn't do it, but you done what you had to do. I can't read no fault in you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm gonna go away tonight. I can't go puttin' this on you folks.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: --she gonna have her baby, but *it* ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Okay, Ma. I shouldn't, though. I know I shouldn't. But okay.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Here come a lot of people.

Speaker: bookkeeper's voice
Dialogue: How many of you?

Speaker: migrant's voice
Dialogue: Ten of us. Whatcha payin'?

Speaker: migrant
Dialogue: Okay, mister. Whatcha payin'?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Two and a half cents.

Speaker: migrant
Dialogue: Two an' a half! Say, mister, a man can't make his dinner on that.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Take it or leave it. There's 200 men coming from the South that'll be glad to get it.

Speaker: migrant
Dialogue: But--but how we gonna eat?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: Look, I didn't set the price. I'm just working here. If you want it, take it. If you don't, turn right around and beat it.

Speaker: migrant
Dialogue: Which way is House 25?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That Casy. He might a been a preacher, but--he seen a lot a things clear. He was like a lantern--he helped mw see things too.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Comes night we'll get outa here.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: It's jus' till we get some distance. Then you can come out.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'd hate to get *trapped* in here.

Speaker: guard's voice
Dialogue: What's goin' on here?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: We're goin' out.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: We got a job offered--good job.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Yeah? Let's have a look at you.  Wasn't there another fella with you?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: I guess that's what he looked like.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: What'd he look like again?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Short fella. Pale face.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Was he bruised up this mornin'? About the face?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: I didn't see nothin'.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Okay. Go on.

Speaker: second guard
Dialogue: Goin' out for good?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Yeah. Goin' north. Got a job.

Speaker: second guard
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You done good, Al. Just good.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Know where we're a-goin'?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Don't matter. Just got to go--an' keep a-goin', till we get plenty a distance away from here.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Ma... you know, if Connie was here I wouldn't min' any a this.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I know, honey, an' just as soon as we get settled Al's gonna set out an' look for him. How 'bout gas, Tommy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Full up. Uncle John come through with five bucks he been hol'in' out on us since we lef' home.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She's hotter'n a heifer.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Fan-belt's shot.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Picks a nice place for it, too, don't she?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Any gas?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Gallon or two?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, looks like we done it this time awright!

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Some smoke up there.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Looks like about a mile. Reckon she'll make it?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: She got to make it.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Don't know--but it's better'n this.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: You hit 'er too fast.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: What's the idea of that?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Well, a lot a kids play in here. You tell folks to go slow and they liable to forget. But let 'em hit that hump once and they don't forget!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Got any room here for us?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Down that line and turn to the left. You'll see it. You'll be in No. 4 Sanitary Unit.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Toilet and showers and washtubs.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You mean you got *washtubs?* An' runnin' water?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.  Camp committee'll call on you in the morning and get you fixed.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Cops?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: No. No cops. Folks here elect their own cops.  Come inside and sign up.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Take 'er on down, Al. I'll sign.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: We gonna stay, ain't we?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You're tootin' we're gonna stay.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: I don't mean to be nosy, y'understand. I just got to have certain information. What's your name?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Joad. Tom Joad.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: How many of you?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: How 'bout it, Uncle John? Gotta pitch this tent.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I'm a-comin'.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You don't look so good.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I *ain't* so good, but--I'm a-comin'.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Camp site costs a dollar a week, but you can work it out, carrying garbage, keeping the camp clean--stuff like that.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We'll work it out. What's this committee you talkin' about?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: We got five sanitary units. Each one elects a central committee man. They make the laws, an' what they say goes.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Are you aimin' to tell me that the fellas that run this camp is jus' fellas--campin' here?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: That's the way it is.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: An' you say no cops?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: No cop can come in here without a warrant.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I can't hardly believe it. Camp I was in once, they burned it out--the deputies an' some of them poolroom fellas.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: They don't get in here. Sometimes the boys patrol the fences, especially dance nights.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You got dances too?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: We got the best dances in the county every Saturday night.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Say, who runs this place?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Government.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why ain't they more like it?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: *You* find out, I can't.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Anything like work aroun' here?

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Can't promise you that, but there'll be a licensed agent here tomorrow mornin', if you want to talk to him.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ma's shore gonna like it here. She ain't been treated decent for a long time.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: That cut you got?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Crate fell on me.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Better take care of it. Store manager'll give you some stuff for it in the morning. Goodnight.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Good mornin'.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Mornin'.

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Git up. I got sump'n to show you.

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: Whatsa matter?

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: It's them white things, made outa dish-stuff, like in the catalogues!

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Come on. Ain't nobody gonna say anything.

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: Won't they ketch us?

Speaker: ruthie's voice
Dialogue: Them's where you wash your han's.

Speaker: winfield's voice
Dialogue: What's these?

Speaker: ruthie's voice
Dialogue: Well, I reckon you *stan'* in them little rooms--an' water come down outa that there little jigger up there--take a bath!

Speaker: winfield's voice
Dialogue: Jes' like in the catalogues, ain't they!

Speaker: ruthie's voice
Dialogue: I seen 'em b'fore you did.

Speaker: winfield's voice
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: ruthie's voice
Dialogue: Now don't you go monk'ing--

Speaker: ruthie's voice
Dialogue: Now you done it! You busted it!

Speaker: winfield's voice
Dialogue: I never--

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: Lissen. You done busted it. You hear?  But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?

Speaker: winfield
Dialogue: Please don't.

Speaker: ruthie
Dialogue: I won't--  --if you won't tell what *I* done!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: If this don't feel good!

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: Wait'll about 'leven o'clock, see how good she feels then!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Seems like a nice frien'ly fella to work for, too.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Lotta these little farmers mighty nice fellas. Trouble is they're little, they ain't got much say-so.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Shore looks like my lucky day, anyway. Gettin' some work at las'.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Lissen here. Maybe I'm talkin' myself outa my farm, but I like you fellas, so I'm gonna tell you. You live in that gov'ment camp, don't you?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: And you have dances every Saturday night?

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: We sure do.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Well, look out next Saturday night.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: What you mean? I belong to the central committee. I got to know.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Don't you ever tell I told.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Like last night. Lissen. "Citizens, angered at red agitators, burn another squatters' camp, warn agitators to get out of the county."

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Listen. What *is* these reds? Ever'time you turn aroun' somebody sayin' somebody else's a red. What is these reds, anyway?

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: Well, I tell you. They was a fella up the country named King--got about 30,000 acres an' a cannery an' a winery--an' he's all a time talkin' about reds. Drivin' the country to ruin, he says. Got to git rid of 'em, he says. Well, they was a young fella jus' come out an' he was listenin one day. He kinda scratched his head an' he says, "Mr. King, what *is* these reds you all a time talkin' about?" Well, sir, Mr. King says, "Young man, a red is any fella that wants thirty cents a hour when I'm payin' twenty-five."

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I ain't talkin' about that one way or the other. All I'm saying is that there's going to be a fight in the camp Saturday night. And there's going to be deputies ready to go in.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: But why? Those fellas ain't botherin' nobody.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I'll tell you why. Those folks in to being treated like humans. Suppose the Government closes its camps. Suppose too many people pass through 'em. Well, when those people go back to the squatters' camps they'll be hard to handle.  Go on back to work now. Maybe I've talked myself into trouble, but you're folks like us, and I like you.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: An' they ain't gonna be no fight, either.

Speaker: committee man
Dialogue: Ev'nin', ma'am. Who'd you say invited you?

Speaker: guests
Dialogue: Mister an' Mizz Clark, they ast us.

Speaker: committee man
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. Come right in, ma'am.

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: Hidy, Mr. Thomas. Hidy, Mizz Thomas.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: You watching out, ain't you?

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: Don't you worry. Ain't gonna be no trouble.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I hope you know what you're talking about.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: Ma...  Ma, I--I can't go to the dance. I jus' can't Ma. I can't hardly stan' it, with Connie not here--an' me this way.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Why, honey, it makes folks happy to see a girl that way--makes folks sort of giggly an' happy.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: I can't he'p it, Ma. It don't make *me* giggly an' happy.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You an' me's goin' together--jus' you an' me. We're a-goin' to that dance an' we're a-goin' to jus' set an' watch. If anybody says to come dance--why I'll say you're poorly. But you an' me, we're gonna hear the music an' see the fun.

Speaker: rosasharn
Dialogue: An' you won't let nobody touch me?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: No--an' look what I got for you.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You'll look pretty in 'em tonight.

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: They tell me you're half Injun. You look all Injun to me.

Speaker: jule
Dialogue: No, jes' half. Wisht I was full- blooded. Gov'ment'd be lookin' out for me an' I'd be ridin' around in a Buick eight.

Speaker: committee man
Dialogue: Who give you the invitation?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Fella named Jackson--Buck Jackson.

Speaker: committee man
Dialogue: Okay. Come on in.

Speaker: jule
Dialogue: Them's our fellas.

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: How you know?

Speaker: jule
Dialogue: Jes' got a feelin'. They're kinda scared too. Follow 'em an' get a holt of Jackson. See if he knows 'em. I'll stay here.

Speaker: fiddler
Dialogue: Swing your ladies an' a dol ce do. Join han's roun' an' away we go! Swing to the right an' a swing to the lef'. Break, now break--back to back!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Thank you kin'ly but she ain't well.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Maybe you wouldn't think it, but your pa was as nice a dancer as I ever seen, when he was young.  Kinda makes me think a ol' times.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I seen 'em before. Worked at Gregorio's with 'em. But I never ast 'em.

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: Awright. Keep your eye on 'em. Jus' keep 'em in sight, that's all.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I seen 'em, Mr. Wallace. A car with six men parked down by the euc'lyptus tree an' one with three men on the main road. They got guns, too. I seen 'em.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Thank you, Willie. You done good.  Well, it looks like the fat's in the far this time.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: What them deppities want to hurt the camp for? How come they can't leave us be?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: What we oughta do, we oughta git us some pickhandles an'--

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: They're here. We got 'em spotted.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You sure you got ever'thing ready?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ain't gonna be no trouble.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You ain't to hurt them fellas.

Speaker: wilkie
Dialogue: You don't have to worry. We got ever'thing arranged. Maybe nobody'll even see it.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Just don't use no stick nor no knife, no piece a arn. An' if you got to sock 'em, sock 'em where they won't bleed.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Awright. An' if she gets outa han', I'll be in the right han' corner, this side the dance floor.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ain't gonna get outa han'.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: Mighty sure a themselves, looks like.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: All I hope, I hope they don't kill nobody.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Gonna dance tonight?  I can waltz.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: That's nothin'--anybody can waltz.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Not like me!

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You git right along! This here girl's spoke for. She's gonna be married, an' her man's a-comin' for her.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She's gettin' prettier, Ma.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Girl with a baby *always* gets prettier.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Well, you said anybody can waltz... How'm *I* doin'?

Speaker: blonde girl
Dialogue: Don't hold me so tight.

Speaker: al
