Dialogue: Why, I ain't hardly touchin' you!

Speaker: blonde girl
Dialogue: You're *ticklin' me!*

Speaker: al
Dialogue: That comes from not holdin' you tight *enough.*

Speaker: blonde girl
Dialogue: Now I can't breathe.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: I'll dance with this girl.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: You an' who else?

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Don't gimme no argament--  --you little--

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Open up! We hear you got a riot.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Riot? I don't see no riot. Who're you?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Deputy sheriffs.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Got a warrant?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: We don't need a warrant if it's a riot.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Well, I don't know what you gonna do about it, because I don't hear no riot an' I don't see no riot, an' what's more I don't believe they *is* no riot.  Look for yourself.

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: You got no right to arrest anybody without a warrant, you know.

Speaker: first cop
Dialogue: We'll have a warrant--just as soon as we check with headquarters.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Ain't you gonna tell me goodbye, Tommy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I didn't know, Ma. I didn't know if I ought.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Come outside.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They was some cops here, Ma. They was takin' down the license numbers. It looks like somebody knows sump'n.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: It had to come, I reckon, soon or later.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'd like to stay. I'd like to be with ya--  --I guess I won't never be able to do that. Not now.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I could hide you, Tommy.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I know you would, Ma. But I ain't gonna let you. You hide somebody that's kilt a man an'... an' you'd be in trouble too.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Awright, Tommy. What you figger you gonna do?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You know what I been thinkin' about, Ma? About Casy. About what he said, what he done, an' about how he died. An' I remember all of it.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: He was a good man.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I been thinkin' about us, too--about our people livin' like pigs, an' good rich lan' layin' fallow, or maybe one fella with a million acres, while a hundred thousan' farmers is starvin'. An' I been wonderin' if all our folks got together an' yelled--

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Tommy, they'll drive you, an' cut you down like they done to Casy.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They gonna drive me anyways. Soon or later they'll get me, for one thing if not another. Until then...

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: You don't aim to kill nobody, Tom!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, Ma. Not that. That ain't it. But long as I'm a outlaw, anyways, maybe I can do sump'n. Maybe I can jus' fin' out sump'n. Jus' scrounge aroun' an' try to fin' out what it is that's wrong, an then see if they ain't sump'n could be done about it.  But I ain't thought it out clear, Ma. I can't. I don't know enough.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: How'm I gonna know 'bout you? They might kill you an' I wouldn't know. They might hurt you. How'm I gonna know?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, maybe it's like Casy says, a fella ain't got a soul of his own, but on'y a piece of a big soul--the one big soul that belongs to ever'body-- an' then...

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Then what, Tom?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Then it don't matter. Then I'll be all aroun' in the dark. I'll be ever'where--wherever you look. Wherever there's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever there's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there. I'll be in the way guys yell when they're mad--an' I'll be in the way kids laugh when they're hungry an' they know supper's ready. An' when our people eat the stuff they raise, an' live in the houses they build, why, I'll be there too.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I don't understan' it, Tom.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Good-by, Tom. Later--when it's blowed over--you'll come back? You'll try to fin' us?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure. Good-by.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Good-by, Tommy.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: What y'all hurryin' so for? Tell me they got twenny days work.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Yes, sir, an' we aim to git in all twenny of 'em.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Ready, Ma?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I'll get Rosasharn.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: All aboard, ever'body! All aboard for Fresno!

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Try to be strong, honey. Someday it'll be diff'rent--someday you'll have another one. You're still jus' a little girl, remember.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Make her easy, John. Watch her.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: She'll be awright.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Ready, Pa?

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Let 'er go, Gallagher!

Speaker: caretaker
Dialogue: Good luck to you! Good luck, ever'body!

Speaker: the joads
Dialogue: Good-by, Mr. Conway! Much oblige to you for ever'thing!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Twenty days work, oh boy!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Be glad to get my han' on some cotton. That's the kin' a pickin' I understan'.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Maybe. Maybe twenny days work, maybe *no* days work. We ain't got it till we get it.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Whatsa matter, Ma? Gettin' scared?

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: I was, though. For a while I thought we was beat--*good* an' beat. Looked like we didn't have nothin' in the worl' but enemies--wasn't *no*body frien'ly anymore. It made me feel bad an' scared too--like we was lost... an' nobody cared.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Watch me pass that Chevvy.

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: You the one that keeps us goin', Ma. I ain't no good any more, an' I know it. Seems like I spen' all my time these days a-thinkin' how it use'ta be--thinkin' of home--an' I ain't never gonna see it no more.

Speaker: ma
Dialogue: Woman can change better'n a man. Man lives in jerks--baby born, or somebody dies, that's a jerk--gets a farm, or loses one, an' that's a jerk. With a woman it's all one flow, like a stream, little eddies, little waterfalls, but the river it goes right on. Woman looks at it like that.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Look at that ol' coffeepot steam!

Speaker: pa
Dialogue: Maybe, but we shore takin' a beatin'.
